Comment: There is a spectrum of masculine & feminine traits in both sexes. It is enforcing certain characteristics on each that creates inner conflict. Peterson should know that gender change is a result of the need to conform to stereotypes, over 90% of male gender reassignments (the most common) are performed on those who worked in highly masculine jobs as a disguise. If the world stopped trying to homogenise gender expectation it would probably cease to be an issue. When female movie stars began wearing trousers there was little reaction & it is now unquestioned. If a man wears a dress it is an abnormal expression of masculinity, this shows a huge disparity of gender freedom. Both masculine & feminine traits (which have an overlap) can be toxic, that is the desire to assert yourself over another. All of these issues are all bound up in the dogma of religion - you should be what we tell you to be - & has spread into various forms of indoctrination. Religion remains an integral part of our society, it has served humanity badly on every level.

Name: steppahouse
Comment: Rising respect for RB in recent months, both as an interviewer and his obvious interest in parsing through our complicated civ. Here, though, he's overthinking it. While I agree with Peterson's comment that RB's hypothesis warrants thought, there's a simpler explanation. For Boomers especially, and carried over into Xrs, the prevailing assumption by the ad market decision-makers has been that regardless that a household only have one income and it was brought in by the man, the woman still made most of the day to day purchasing decisions, was assumed to use most of the products more often. After spending a couple of decades with that template, and as commercials became more sophisticated, were got more humor. Men have typically been the comic foils in mass media (though there are notable exceptions). However, even in the 90's, maybe due to something like Simpsonifocation or AlBundying, lol, we started seeing a LOT of the boyfriend/husband/father as the oaf, idiot, simpleton. Like...alllll the time.

Name: Lorna Long
Comment:
For some 20 years I was a single mother and breadwinner and found myself having to 'do battle' with many people and circumstances in order to be both mother and provide for my 2 daughters.

My friends at the time, being quite esoteric folks, told me I was 'too masculine' . That I needed to work on being 'more feminine'.

My point of view was that when you need to do battle, probably a war negotiation or a battle axe is going to serve me better than whatever 'more feminine' means.

Now that my daughters are adults, independent and professionals in their own careers, my friends comment on not 'knowing how I did it'  (balancing career, motherhood, children with learning disorders, multiple therapists, teachers who did not understand and an acrimonious ex-husband, various legal battles he threw at me, financing all the extra therapies plus everything 2 young people in today's world need - for all of 2 decades). The answer is 'I had to go Viking' on it all.

My daughters were unhappy when I was clearly not 'as available' as they would have liked growing up. But I made sure we had plenty of family times and time out together in nature in the little leisure time we had.

Now they understand the example and picture I gave them.  They are fully able to embrace both masculine & feminine sides to their humanness - the workplace and potential partners are NOT particularly ready for that though.

They are just not your average women. They have fully embraced their 'masculine' side with being definitely women who mean business in today's world. At home, (metaphorically speaking) they are definitely not used to giving up the remote. We never had that issue in a 3-woman household.

Embracing both sides is just not comfortable for women. There is still enormous stereotyping working against women being "allowed" to be that. Women are frequently 'punished severely' - at home, in social groups and even quite definitively in the workplace where equality of competence should be most of tolerated.

Name: Knowledge is Power
Comment: It was a bit 'car crash tv' but there was a programme a while back called 'Young, Dumb and Living with Mum' which stuck a group of 18 yr olds in a house together and monitored them.  Most (all?) were coming from homes where their parents were in despair over their Childs' 'laziness' or inability to cope with the most basic tasks.  It was truly shocking to see 18yr olds asking for advice on how to heat up a tin of beans or turn on a washing machine. It suggested the kind of parenting Jordan speaks of here.   I don't want to point fingers - people can slip into habits, or make a simple mistake that just snowballs - but really if a child from a supposedly stable home is reaching 18 with no idea how to make a meal for itself or wash its own clothes the parents have to take a look at themselves!  You are not helping your children by smothering them with care and leaving them unable to take care of themselves (even if you're rich and think you'll always be able to pay someone to do things for you, you should still know how to take care of essential needs.  Never say never.

Name: Kathryn Preuss
Comment: Umm... the Evil Queen/Stepmother architype is evil because...overprotective??? Did we read the same fairytales growing up? I distinctly recall a poisoned apple. Also, the 4th element is either the female or the devil. Yup, that sounds like our mythology. One of the first things I learned growing up was that female = bad and male = good. "You run like a girl." "You throw like a girl." "You hit like a girl." "Girls don't understand math / 3D spatial reasoning / insert "smart" topic here." I don't think the phrase "toxic masculinity" means that masculinity is toxic, and I think it is disingenuous to imply that this is what is meant. Being an a-hole is toxic, but that a-holery is acceptable, even lauded, if you are a "masculine man".

Name: Mark Fennell
Comment:
Masculinity does not negate femininity. It is catalysed by femininity. The submissiveness of feminity is active, and primary with regard to agency. However, femininity uncoupled from maternalism becomes an exercise in pointlessness, exploited by the social engineers to destroy masculinity. The strategy of saturating the public arena with sensationalised female sexuality, while simultaneously pathologizing the natural masculine response to it is derived from Pavlovs experiments in which he manufactured neurosis in dogs by simultaneously issuing excitory and inhibitory commands, throwing a stick and at the same time saying stay.

"The possible relevance of these experiments to sudden religious and political conversion should be obvious even to the most sceptical: Pavlov has shown by repeated and repeatable experiment just how a dog, like a man, can be conditioned to hate what it previously loved, and love what it previously hated. Similarly, one set of behaviour patterns in man can be temporarily replaced by another that altogether contradicts it; not by persuasive indoctrination alone, but also by imposing intolerable strains on a normally functioning brain."

William Sargant, Battle for the Mind.

Comment:
Young men need role models and unfortunately, there aren't as many in local communities and in the media the message of what a man should be and how he should act is completely shattered. Luckily there are y few Channels that share useful messages like Jocko Podcast, Mastery Order, Order of Man, Jordan B. Peterson.

Name: Jan Vyachaslav
Comment:
​@Collan Everyone is different, yes, and you should pursue what you want in life, but the fact that you don't have to fight and protect yourself and the fact that you don't need to be physically and mentally strong to survive is because there are other people doing it for you.
The fact that you can be "feminine" and only express that part into the world is a comfort that comes from the effort of other people that do what you don't do or refuse to do. This is fine, but never pretend that this should be the norm and men should be like that all the time.
Your freedom of expression and the comfort that you enjoy today comes from the peaceful times provided by men and women that are prepared mentally and physically to keep the peace.
All the best to you!

Name: Collan
Comment:
@Jan Vyachaslav The thing is that is YOUR decision, there are other ways to help people and be part of a community. The beautiful thing about humanity that everyone is different, someone will be physically strong, someone will be mentally strong and everything between.
We dont live in the 15 century where we have to fight wars every day, we fortunately born in a century where you can express yourself.

Name: Jan Vyachaslav
Comment:
@Collan I am a husband and a father and a volunteer firefighter, and besides being joyful and embracing emotions, when it comes to my family and the people around me, I am also the one that is there in case of emergencies, whether these are financial emergencies, physical dangers or other challenges that life throws in our way.
I am there for the people that I care about, and not only emotionally. I have trained and continue to train myself mentally and physically so that I can be prepared for difficult periods, because I choose to be the one standing in front of the fire when my family or the small community around me faces such a threat.
Life is not about you and you alone. Life is about you and your family and community, and to be able ensure their well being, as well as yours, you have to be willing to not think of yourself as much and get down to business and do the hard and dirty and dangerous things that have to be done.
All the best to you!

Name: Bob Nevels
Comment:
Or maybe the commodification in consumerism makes the light available to allow men to embody the feminine independently of having access to a spouse. Women taught me that it's more important to build my own world through consumerism than to be attached to the feminine by need of the feminine. Consumerism actually would make it possible to mitigate and make prostitution less a thing. If a man can own his own spiritual sexuality then women wouldn't have that debt to men, which actually liberates women.

Basically men can't respect women unless they don't need women. And the sad thing is women had been conditioned to believe that being needed and being respected are the same thing, and they're not, which is why women have had a tendency to oppress themselves to show how needed they are, and that's how women held themselves back, because of confusing need with respect. Respect is more secure than need. But women have seemed to have been taught that if she is needed then she is secure, and that's a logical fallacy. Because need created neediness in men that created spiritual poverty in men that created an abusive relationship of some males relationship to women, that women themselves had created in part. I say in part not to blame, because women had been victimized to some degree, but identifying as a victim means that a woman's pride as victim is what keeps a woman a spiritual prisoner, and the good news of that is that a woman can just walk out of that prison at will.

In my private life I've sometimes been hard on the female perspective in relating the traps of some women to men, but my point with that is it doesn't matter what who did to who, be strong and protect yourself and it's better for all involved to dismiss victim narratives, because those narratives often had the argument that because this or that group had been hurt that you should just let yourself be hurt, and that's just fucking stupid. That's not natural. There's something animalistic and righteous in dismissing the past and respecting ones own humanity. Then human decency has a blank slate. And that's something only individuals can give themselves.

The logical fallacy of the Koran though as interpreted by some is that it's logically impossible to make the world into a world wide caliphate, because that assumed that Gods work with everyone else was a mistake that needed to be erased and that's arrogant that directly contradicts the best value of Middle Eastern culture, which is humility. Humility implies a willingness to learn listen and grow with other human beings, not control or.dominate other human beings. White people have had a past. The best wisdom of white culture is that light shines naturally when home is honored and not earned. Cherished. White history and past racism had contradicted that value, but that doesn't mean that value isn't there, because it is. Simplifying value of the family makes great cultural achievements. Versailles and several other shameless over expensive buildings weren't built for the sake of oppression. The spiritual debt there was there and couldn't not be there. Part of the tragedy of human history, but using that temporary moment of injustice to make something beautiful is one step of grace to eliminate injustice. 

Black culture is one of strength and resilience. Shaka Zulu created a mythology of warriors who could walk anywhere because their feet had no shoes. But that same formlessness led to an arrogance that seemed to confuse strength with valuing nothing. One strong black man once said love was a weakness. And that's wrong. But I also listened to his insights. Love needs to incorporate business sense or love is weak. That was me being willing to listen and respect black insight to strengthen my relationship with my own cultural insight about home and the clarity that inevitability brings and the sense of humility and willingness to fearlessly learn from someone else that would possibly be the best form of middle eastern culture. 

Courage is something all cultures share.

To prevent catastrophe I'm the anomaly in white culture. My wisdom has had a natural prince of darkness quality, and as a cultural exchange in the nineteenth century I traveled to Africa and functioned as a priest with Shaka Zulu for future mutual benefit.

We created a common mind of mutual wisdom. Thats what happened.

Name: Black Bordello
Comment: This is such an archaic reading of gender symbols in culture. Yes the devouring mother is one archetype, the overbearing overprotective figure who needs to mollycoddle their children in order to have a sense of purpose, for without them they are gone. But gender has changed massively in the turn of the century because the archetype of the overarching, omniscient, omnipotent father has gone. Rarely does this archetype exist in a family anymore. In fact what we have now is a dislocation in the way men are taught to be providers, defenders and strategists but they are not routinely sent out to war anymore and taught to fight. In fact, the lines between hormonal makeup of both sexes are blurring, hence paving the way for less paradoxical and concrete definitions of either. This is by cause of nature, as a result of nurture. The time when these biblical and Victorian fables were written were times when men had a great weight of demands and responsibility which society does not demand of them as much anymore - before then and in more collectivist societies, women were routinely seen as power figures and the bodies were worshipped beyond commodification, eg Kali goddess of War, Athena, etc. Also, the body would respond hormonally to a man who went to war, producing more fight hormones, whereas now a man sitting at a desk would not need as high a production level of the fight hormones. This poses greater freedom to all genders when deciphering themselves as autonomous beings, now somewhat less defined by the parts between their legs but subject to environments and, most importantly, their choices.

This is also true with the increase of focus, belated though it is, for attention to the LGBTQXYZ, etc. segments of society who, until  recently, have been nearly invisible.  THOUGH I UNDERSTAND AND APPRECIATE THE NEED TO HAVE PAID ATTENTION AND INCREASED AWARENESS OF ALL THESE GROUPS, it can be kind of hard hearing for almost all of my life, close to 50 years, the men are bad and are responsible for all the ills of the world. Name: Citizen 337
Comment: Yes, the Tetragrammaton maps a Tetrahedron geometrically. If you have 3 points of a perfect Tetrahedron, the 4th point is implied mathematically and known. In the Name of God (aka the Tetragrammaton), there are four letters - Yod-Heh-Vau-Heh. Yod is the point of origin, and corresponds to the male. Heh is the space around the point of origin - geometrically expressed by the radius from the origin. This is why female is a vessel, the womb. You see this in reproductive geometry too - sperm are tiny, like the origin point and the egg is huge, like the sphere determined around the origin. Then you have Vau which means "son, but is the repeat of the original male origin point, but is 90 degrees out of phase rotationally with the original origin point. The 4th point is Heh again, which is the female again - the consort of the Son, or the sister, as in Apollo and Athena. But that second female is implied not in to lower the female aspect, but simply because it is the 4th point geometrically. The 90 degree phase shift of the second pair of points is where spin comes from. You must have the male AND the female (1st two points) to have polarity, and you must have the second pair to get movement and spin. The 4th point is necessary, but is implied by the geometry of the first 3 points. The first 3 points correspond to the Holy Trinity.

Name: Alex Lekas
Comment:
Attacking masculinity is not good for women. Not that long ago, there was a series of articles with professional women lamenting the shortage of financially suitable male partners. Two things to unpack: 1) that women still view men, at least in part, in terms of their earning/providing capacity, but also 2) how the idea to empower women became a zero-sum game in practice. 

College enrollments skew majority female today. Historically, women have married at an equal or higher economic level whereas men have traditionally married at an equal or lower level. That, of course, was before opportunities for women became more widespread. Fewer men in college means fewer at the equal/higher economic level, at least in a "professional" sense. It is not often that a college-educated woman marries an electrician, carpenter, welder, or other tradesman who makes a nice living.

Name: GoatCreature
Comment:
"80% of YouTube users are male" - Such a ludicrous, untrue statement. He is either speaking confidently out of ignorance or is wilfully lying. Either way, the words are coming straight from his ass.

Two of the largest sections of YouTube are childrens entertainment, which splits the genders in half, and makeup tutorials. Second to that are the Paul Brothers brand of "entertainment" which draws in overwhelmingly female audiences. Only gaming can be placed amongst the top wherein it swings overwhelmingly male.

YouTube's entire structure is female dominated. The Vlog Brothers were early on capturing a huge female audience, and they're the ones who made VidCon, the annual YouTube creator convention, which itself is attended mostly by females. The earliest large YouTubers tended to draw in overwhelmingly female audiences as well; Charlieissocoollike, Dan and Phil, Jeffree Star, Trisha Paytas, Jenna Marbles, and the list goes on. And more recently, The Paul Brothers and their ilk.

The reason Peterson's audience is 80% male is because he spends his days attempting to capture disaffected male youth like they're fucking pokémon. It's a part of his grift. To claim that his audiences are representative of YouTube as a whole is laughable and disingenuous; he himself has expressed confusion and concern as to why his audience is so male dominated, as was the case in a tweet on the 3rd of March 2017 at 7:37pm in which he said "91% of those who view my videos are male. Why? Why few women?"

This new angle reeks to me of some kind of death rattle. An ostrich burying his head in the sand. To accept openly that his messaging only narrowly appeals to men because of its sexist undertones and the specificity of his content which is effectively just Alcoholics Anonymous self-help bullshit from the 1970s would be a deathblow to his ego, I feel.

Name: Abigail O'Rourke
Comment:
Peterson is saying problems arise when we don't invite in/make space for the Devouring Mother/crone/witch/feminine chaos/whatever you want to call it... i.e. Sleeping Beauty ends up unconscious.

Based on the myth he's referencing, if the Devouring Mother is a problem in our society, is this not evidence that something might be lacking...? An invitation, maybe? 🤔

Peterson spends his time advocating AGAINST the overmothering behaviors/archetype... Yeah dude, duh, Maleficent is powerful and vengeful and scary... We know! He also acknowledges the feminine has BOTH positive and negative arcs, i.e. Fairy Godmother and Evil Witch. 

So what would have happened if Sleeping Beauty's parents apologized to Maleficent and invited her to the next party?

What if we advocated FOR the Witch to be invited in the first place, so we don't spend the rest of the movie (aka our lives) fighting?

Oh right, because we LOVE the drama of it all! 😆 It wouldn't be a good movie if we didn't have a bad villain... 

In real life, if we want meaningful change we have to stop making villains out of each other. It seems to me Peterson would rather keep making his point "overmothering is bad" rather than thoughtfully engage with the Devouring Mother herself.

If I were having an intimate conversation with Peterson myself I would ask him, what if you actually LOVE being devisive and controversial? What if you truly enjoy getting strong reactions from people by belabouring emotional, difficult topics with evasive and academic language? What if you accepted you are really GOOD at doing just that? And what if that is a totally normal and amazing phenomenon, and what would happen if we observed it and savored it and used in a cooler, more effective way??? Why deny the drama??? You bring it with you everywhere 😉

Since you will be called my brother, it is not fitting that you be ignorant of yourself. Jesus said, "It is in light that light exists."

22- The Savior said, All Nature, all formations, all creatures exist in and with another, and they will be resolved again into their own roots.

Name: Rubim Ellmelech
Comment:
The Principle of Gender:

"Gender is in everything; everything has its Masculine and Feminine Principles; Gender manifests on all planes."--The Kybalion.

This Principle embodies the truth that there is GENDER manifested in everything--the Masculine and Feminine Principles ever at work. This is true not only of the Physical Plane, but of the Mental and even the Spiritual Planes. On the Physical Plane, the Principle manifests as SEX, on the higher planes it takes higher forms, but the Principle is ever the same. No creation, physical, mental or spiritual, is possible without this Principle. An understanding of its laws will throw light on many a subject that has perplexed the minds of men. The Principle of Gender works ever in the direction of generation, regeneration, and creation. Everything, and every person, contains the two Elements or Principles, or this great Principle, within it, him or her. Every Male thing has the Female Element also; every Female contains also the Male Principle. If you would understand the philosophy of Mental and Spiritual Creation, Generation, and Re-generation, you must understand and study this Hermetic Principle. It contains the solution of many mysteries of Life. We caution you that this Principle has no reference to the many base, pernicious and degrading lustful theories, teachings and practices, which are taught under fanciful titles, and which are a prostitution of the great natural principle of Gender. Such base revivals of the ancient infamous forms of Phallicism tend to ruin mind, body and soul, and the Hermetic Philosophy has ever sounded the warning note against these degraded teachings which tend toward lust, licentiousness, and perversion of Nature's principles. If you seek such teachings, you must go elsewhere for them--Hermeticism contains nothing for you along these lines. To the pure, all things are pure; to the base, all things are base.

Name: Bon Tempo
Comment:
It's simple.  The fake culture of the internet, has affected real life. And another bad thing about that, is that internet culture has alot of young generations running through it. Often, people are not even thinking about the age of who is making a comment.
And the problem with that is, young people honestly don't know shit yet lol.  We ALL think we did when we was that age, but once you've been around the block, you really get to see what it's all about.
 So back to my main point, why is it bad that fake internet culture has affected real life, because there is NOOO respect anymore. Respect was a social evolution. Respect is intelligent. Respect is a marker that life is understood and we understand natural thresholds based on consequences and what is worthwhile. It's long sighted, it's healthy, it makes life better, easier, safer.
And respect has totally gone. Nobody respects anyone or anything anymore !! So suddenly, all our structures are taken away, and we are left to react like animals in defence of our humiliation, attacks, safety, pride, ego, etc.  It's basically social anarchy.  It's people saying 'fuck them, fuck that, i'll do what i want' - read that like a stroppy teenager, and it will help you see how immature that mentality is. And of course it's immature, because it came from the young generations.
Without respect, we attack each other. We cross lines. We push deep into each other. We destroy structures of masculinity and femininity and replace it with the current mess that makes people feel like the world is ending, or at least this civilisation.

Name: SuperBluesify
Comment:
One thing I noticed Peterson plays up is peoples’ complicated relationships with their mothers. I think some people out there naturally have resentment towards their mothers because to be frank their moms might have been overbearing, abusive, emotionally unregulated and so on but Peterson says the solution is more masculine upbringing or a disconnect from the mom. I think he’s wrong here but since it plays into peoples anger they hear someone speaking to their unresolved emotions and think it’s true. Their anger feels now justified in blame. There’s another option Peterson is missing. That option is for the mom to get the help she needs so she doesn’t have that type of relationship with her son or children. I don’t think it’s an issue with masculinity or femininity, I think it’s an issue with emotion regulation skills,
mindfulness and bringing that to child rearing. there are plenty of families who never stop having close relationships with their parents or just one of their parents and it’s healthy because the parents were initially healthy. But they are the exception, and people struggling with mental health is a big issue in America and I think Peterson in a self important way monetarily takes advantage of that.

Name: Pryde Foltz
Comment:
"Is is an idea worth thinking about for a while" ... that is called diplomacy. LOL.  

The thing is men consume as much as women and we both have an instinct to bring back sustenance to the family and tribe in one way or another. For a long time, it was tasked to women to do most of the shopping for the household and so the advertising was mostly targeted towards women. I think it may be more of a case of situational legacy than that consuming is a misplaced worship of the feminine. I mean have we really stopped worshipping yin and yang energies is other ways ... if you know what I mean. Ask your wife. This is obviously  also  part of advertising tactics. 

To the devouring mother; she has of course been denied an outlet for her divine sexuality and as such her energies become over-focused on nurturing her children because the egos natural drive to free itself, we get contrast between child and parent. A lack of balance generally experienced through resentment is where the suffering and demonization begins.  The devouring parent is a very dangerous misogynist concept  and used to disenfranchise women from politic power. The racial hatred portion aside, calling a woman a 'Karen' removes the place for the elder female at the council. It silences wisdom as it flows through older women. De-sexed and silenced what role is left her but that of child-nurturer. This is why we continue to need feminism. 

If we want to avoid imbalance in our relationships ... and really that is what you are both getting at; situations and relationships only become 'toxic' when there is an imbalance. Men and women, non-binaries, must be freer to explore identity without dualistic bounds and expectations. The individual should be free to flow between the yin and yang concepts and not limited by either. 

I think the only real limit any enlightening individual needs is the golden rule. Treat others (and the environment) as you would wish to be treated. This requires empathetic abilities which are natural for some and can be taught through role-play and thought experiments for others. 

As a feminist ... systems should not be constructed to disadvantage/advantage any group of people over another, and we should all have equal rights under the law, I find this talk about masculinity and femininity counter-productive and animosity-driving. It literally pits feminists (just a word) against feminists. (Let's just say people who are pro-equality and anti-oppression. That's just about all of us.) 

When you have the balance right, you will know because you feel and look good. Others will note it and feel good to be around you. We all want to feel free but also supported and appreciated. Remember this and remember it is not your job to get the balance right for another because you can't. Appreciate them and allow them the space to gain their own balance, but certainly, particularly if they have soft cranial parts, keep them from falling to their death.  Gentleness and age appropriate limits make sense and if you are particularly artful at applying them, a child will appreciate them and may not even notice you have.

(Get the full blog here ... https://peakd.com/photography/@prydefoltz/russell-brand-in-conversation-jordan-peterson-response-blog-digital-art-and-photography)

Name: Josephine Gutierrez
Comment:
Dear Russel. I know you probably won't read this, however, I feel the need to express it.
I stopped watching tv or commercial movies about 20 years ago (inner preservation). I knew you existed as a celebrity only because I remember seeing your face and hearing your name in passing on  occasions when I happened to be in a place where the TV was on and got a glimpse when passing by. I guessed you were kind of famous or something at the time. 

This is to say that I just knew a bit more about you a few weeks ago when one of your videos appeared as a suggestion in my youtube channel. I read the video title and although I don't remember at this moment what it was about, I do remember being curious that a celebrity was talking about certain subjects. Only then I watched the one titled ¨Does fame make you insane?¨ 

I don't mean to sound cruel, but  I am glad that you went through several experiences. Now It is like your spiritual powers have been restored because the wisdom and depth you gained from them now enables you not only to live life fully but also to help others to learn more about so many important topics that now more than ever we all need to get a grip on. I enjoy watching you explaining things, information and communicating your ideas in such a thoughtful, intelligent and articulated manner.Above all, I find beauty, truth and love in your words.

I´m also glad for the hard experiences I went through because I have also gained wisdom. That's why now  I can really appreciate the work you´re doing and understand your ideas, many of them are reflections of my own. You also make me laugh a lot and I LOVE laughing.

I hope I have expressed my ideas properly. English is not my native tongue, so please forgive any typos or grammar mistakes.
 I am happy you´re here with us. Thank you.

Name: scruffy makaveli
Comment: It depends on what the kid needs rather than what it wants. Fairy godmothers in movies help out a lot but they don't do everything. The fairy godmother gave snow white a beautiful dress in order to have a chance at winning the heart of the prince. The godmother didn't outright gave her the keys to his heart. Gandalf always rescued the Hobbits in dangerous situations, yet he couldn't bear the ring for Frodo. I think what Jordan is trying to say is simple, We should try our best to give our kids what they NEED instead of what they WANT.

Name: Matthew Villalobos
Comment: I think the scale of the rescue is the point. No child needs to be rescued from setting the dinner table. But that doesn't mean you don't avert catastrophe if it's imminent. Ex. I have a nephew working hard on his independence. He got ripped off on a car deal and lost his mode of transportation and a couple grand of his own money. His grandma and I helped him make a better decision on who to buy a car from and pitched in to make sure it was the right car to keep his life on track. We're not swooping in to save the day every time something goes wrong, but we're also not going to let him fall into squalor because he can't get to and from work.

Name: Julia O'Shaughnessy
Comment: I think Masculinity in men should be encouraged, celebrated and given legitimate purpose. I agree pushing this down has serious detrimental affects. A lot of young males who are attracted to terrorist groups- it is because of the 'celebration and ability to express' their traditionally masculine traits - fighting, honour, 'protecting' against threat, bravery, leadership. Western world closes off access to occupations which would utilise these 'masculine' traits - eg., UK now needs a 'degree' to be a police officer. Equally, I like your theory that the oppression of females has led to the celebration of divine feminine through the only accepted mainstream avenue left - consumerism and the objectification of the female body. It's probably not a coincidence that 80% of people in 'spiritual' circles are women (don't quote me on the percentage lols). The crone definitely represents how invisible women become when we're older/less attractive - therefore culturally irrelevant. Maleficent ('male-efficient') portrayed as the Alpha Female - strong, but therefore evil and must be defeated being stabbed by Prince Philips 'sword of truth'. It's amazing how women have been encouraged to be 'independent', but I can tell you it's the quickest way to end up single lols! All my whiney, weak, bit selfish, disorganised female friends (like the Murphy's I'm not bitter love them really lols) are married with lovely guys. All the strong, independent, career minded women who don't take any cr@p - single, single, single. Society doesn't like alpha females - unless they're comedians, and often even not then unless it's self-flagellating comedy.. that might not be the right word, but you know what I mean lols. Tony Robbins 'Not my Guru' had a 'devouring mother'. The 'shadow' of ourselves must be incorporated, integrated, loved and accepted to stop it growing in the darkness and turning into the part of ourselves that lashes out and self-sabotages our success. The 'othering' of the shadow of ourselves leads to the shadowing of anything in our external lives which we see as 'other' - therefore creating division, at a time, when as you say - unity, collaboration, understanding what makes us 'the same' rather than different to each other is the most important goal. Society seems to be in a process of 'othering' masculinity and I find it quite an abusive process (towards males) to watch if I'm honest. I'm glad guys like Jordan are 'bringing it back', maybe less young men will feel hopeless and want to become INCELS or terrorists. Anyway, wasn't expecting to blather on like that. PS: I watch a LOT of youtube, but only heard of Jordan through this series. The algorithym Gods did not favour you until now Jordan lols.

Name: Brian Dygert
Comment: The fairy godmother didn't do anything for Cinderella except that which she had no means of doing for herself. She did not magic up a new and better life for Cinderella. She gave Cinderella only what was needed materially and some instruction, I.e. don't be late coming home. That is what a good parent is supposed to do. The devouring mother type would have simply conjured the new life and husband to.completion, forever robbing Cinderella of the adventure and necessary pain that goes with it as she found her own way to success. In this case it was marrying the Prince. In your case it may be a career or family, whatever it is that you find truly valuable. That, I think was the point.

Seems like every 3 sentences there is a gay joke or the sentence can be seen as “sus” similar to saying “ I like sausages”. Now I see laughter come from these, but also it is almost like there isn’t an option, if one does not properly receive a gay joke they are met with “ that means you are gay in the inside”. Or something around the lines that they do not know themselves. This doesn’t make sense to me, if you go just one generation back there was no such a thing even as a form of laughter, if I tell my dad something sus like I so much hear he will surely give me an eyebrow raise, not out of disappointment or anything like that but instead like “ what did he just say, where did that come  from?” Bc you are basically hitting on your bro like you would a girl you like, but you just laugh it off. I have heard the phrase “we are all a little gay inside” perhaps it is just about accepting it. But my answer to this is after 6 years of gay jokes becoming common around me it just isn’t funny anymore. I eventually am gonna stop laughing when my bro says “ let me suck yo dick” or getting my ass slapped or calling eachother daddy yet it is taken as being secretly gay to do so. Feel free to put your most sincere answer. I am only looking to understand this phenomenon. I also should mention it seems to be a culture thing, my cousin who grew up in Mexico also raised his eyebrow at a balls joke he heard. This guy is definitely a macho man and good with woman so I know he is not gay as to say. Thank you for any output you have on this.

In short, (I hate to have to use this term, but here goes), it functions to support a patriarchal system. Name: Lord Feder
Audrey R
Comment:
@Lord Feder I'm glad this gave you some food for thought :)

I wouldn't necessarily say that roles are exchanging, because there is a significant gap between the mainstream discourse, which is mostly intended to make money (think of those Disney remakes where we're being told that their only reason to exist is because the original female character was not strong enough...), and reality. That is why it is so important to listen to people instead of making opinions based on what we see online, especially considering how toxic social media can be.

For instance, you're saying that you've had issues with people for being too feminine as a man, but where is the real issue: feminist discourses that aim at freeing people from expectations based on their gender, or a vision of masculinity that doesn't allow men to express their feminine side? 
As someone who was raised by a soldier with PTSD, I can tell you that he made me hate myself so much as a woman that for a really long time I even resented feminine men for feeling free to express a side of themselves that I was suppressing in me. It took me many years to deconstruct everything that I had inherited from his way of seeing the world. The problem is that unlearning things is so hard that a lot of young people would rather follow the same path that made their parents suffer. That's why a lot of young men would rather "man up" than put this injunction into question.. Of course, being too agreeable is never a good thing, but it's up to you to assess if self-confidence will come with more masculinity, or by actually coming to terms with who you are, no matter what everyone else expects from you...

Name: GreyHunter
Comment:
@trey darling I understand where you're coming from, but I think you're missing a key nuance. 

These original groups had protections in place which in effect restricted speech, because the provisions were a list of things you could not do. You could NOT restrict service to a certain racial group. You could NOT refer to homosexuals in the workplace with offensive slurs. 

The gender identity marker is unique in that it can require proactive effort on behalf of the other party. If someone says they want to be referred to by a certain pronoun, you HAVE to refer to them as such or it can be seen as a violation. 

A hypothetical would be if legislation were to pass that could effectively force everyone to refer to Jews as "The Chosen Peoples" or be considered anti-Semitic. There is clearly a big difference in not being able to discriminate against someone for being Jewish, and having to call someone a member of "The Chosen People". 

This situation sounds ridiculous, but it's the same line of reasoning, and could be supported with the same arguments as enforcing self-selected pronouns. This is why the trans-issue was a flashpoint, because it was a unique situation. 

I am fairly confident that the overwhelming majority of people who were critical of bill C-16 had no issues with trans-people in general. The truth is simply that if not calling someone by their pronouns becomes equivalent to calling someone an ethnic slur, then you have no choice but to call people what they dictate, and your speech has been compelled. 

Obviously I understand the argument that this is mainly about protecting trans-people from things like not being given housing or educational opportunities, and that this compelled speech thing won't ever be enforced. The issue is that government rarely decides to roll back its power, and once something is in law, precedent makes it much easier to apply that same rule somewhere else. So these tiny details matter.

Name: Gladys Lucas
Comment:
@Wazzlopio K No, I'm coming at this from a long time massive JP fan. I've seen hundreds of hours of JP videos. I'm giving a meta-analysis of his entire public works. And his first book is a perfect example of him taking very basic, known concepts and dressing them up in obscure intellectual language to make him sound profound, when really he's just saying things that everyone already knows. Example (from Maps of Meaning): "In the purely intrapsychic sphere, such conflict often emerges when attainment of what is desired presently necessarily interferes with attainment of what is desired (or avoidance of what is feared) in the future." ...  translation - So sometimes your short-term and long-term goals conflict...

No need to dress it all up like he does, most of the things he's saying are very basic.

Name: Wazzlopio K
Comment: @Gladys Lucas if you listen to his critic’s cuts of his interviews you can easily get that impression. If you try watch the proper length videos, or even better: read his book, you get a much clearer idea of what he is actually saying.

Name: Gladys Lucas
Comment: @Hannah ☀️ It's hard to pin him down on things because he makes so many descriptive arguments without any prescriptions for those arguments. He's very vague in his language which can lead the audience to draw misguided conclusions. Example: Peterson: "we don't know what to do about the problem of women in the workplace, and women wearing makeup is sexually provocative". He leaves it at that, open ended. And much of his audience then interprets that as 'women are at fault for being provocative in the workplace'. But if you were to ask JP if this was his message, he'd go "no no no I'm not saying that it's women's fault, I'm just saying it's a problem". You can never pin him down on anything, because he's vague and non-prescriptive in his arguments. But his audience sure as hell draws conclusions from his descriptions, often counter-productive conclusions. For more detailed analysis search for the article: The intellectual we deserve.

Name: Maitrī
Comment: The problem with these kinds of argumentations is actually the same that creates the presumably “extremist feminist positions” (which I would not define as properly feminist at all – they are so only in the eyes of right-wing and conservative commentators that want to obscure the real issues behind social inequalities). Both are embedded in an ideological battle around the definition of "man" and "female". But we have to change those paradigms. A strong distinction between allegedly masculine and feminine core-traits brings no good whatsoever. This distinction could have some biological basis - differences in neurobiology as well as obviously different physical features - but the problem arises when we feel the need to define a distinction based on culturally created features. Let's elaborate that. Maybe we should just start to think about us as humans and to define the "positivity" of our being in the world in relation to what we do for others, not in relation to our gender or other overarching categories. It's not important to be a "man", as well as it's not important to be a "woman". Those categories work only inside the same fundamental structure, that is the cultural distinction of gender-traits and the subsequential power-dynamics that our culture had created in the past. Let me clarify. The reason why women strive toward a legitimate and just equality with men has to be found in the prior, unjust distinction between the genders that a male- and powercentric society had created. We had firstly created a distinction that goes beyond the mere biological differentiation of the genders (men and woman) and then we established a hierarchy in which men sat at the top and women were the "weak, subordinate gender". Within this theoretical structure, it's normal and just that women want to be empowered and want to restore a gender equality that has been negated. We, as humanity, have literally suppressed and subjugated a part of our own species, in the same way that has been done with racism and other forms of oppression. But (and that's the tricky part that could upset more than somebody): if we don't posit any differentiation, the rest of the theoretical and hierarchical structure literally falls apart. You can "adhere" to an allegedly female or masculine representation of what you are and that's fine, in the sense that's a free choice. The problem is that we don't really need it. If we could just give up to such a power-related necessity of distinction, men wouldn't need to defend themselves, because there would be nothing to defend (masculinity? what's that? I'm just a human being, with individual and unique traits of whatever kind). And, if and only if we change paradigm, women wouldn't need to fight for their empowerment, because there wouldn't be any power structure and oppression in the first place. There's no strong, powerful, assertive etc. masculinity to defend, because that's an illusion (letting aside the fact that those characteristics are inherently violent to a certain extent and, maybe, should be substituted with a culture of compassion, individual freedom and vulnerability). In this case, we would be human beings, doing and working and living in society which embraces the differences, without creating distinctions. What matters is what we do for other people and for our own happiness. All other discussions, such as the one in this video, are only a way to spread unnecessary violence and distinction that we don't need.

Name: whokilled JR
Comment:
@LOSTINFICTIONENGLAND I'm not american to start off with. To address your post, both genders have behavioral traits that evoke different responses with pros and cons for both. Consider this, you're sitting in an office and a male colleague breaks down bawling his eyes out. Are you going to feel compelled to wrap your arms around him and comfort him? You'd either be lying or not thinking about it considerably if you said yes, we're not built in a way to be protective or emotionally supportive to men around us. Rather what happens is a feeling of awkwardness. On the odd occasion in my life when I've shown such emotion, the looks i get from others are that of "wtf", ok, ok, you're an alien, this is awkward, just be ok now.
In an office if there's a confrontation between a male and female and it gets emotional, regardless of who's in the right it's the female that gets the sympathy and the male that's most likely going to be on the receiving end of a stern talk with the manager.
This behavior extends into all walks of life. Safety measures are taken much more seriously and action is often taken if a women is a casualty at work, in spite of the fact that it's 95% men. This happened in canada, where an accident at work to a female caused the industry to upgrade it's safety measures and ended up likely saving thousands of men over the years.
There's also the prison sentencing gap
